And finally, our project focuses on the design of accessible infrastructure, so we believe that it fits the Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure goal as well.

name: Project Simoy
description: This is a collection of data visualization projects that gives a “breezy” experience to all data enthusiasts.

SDGs.evidenceText: This data visualization projects shows the awarded renewable projects under PH Department of Energy’s National Renewable Energy Program. This aims to start the energy conversation towards into a sustainable energy source of the Philippines.

This data visualization project shows the Air Quality Index (AQI) for some locations in NCR, Region 3, Region 4A, Region 4B and Region 12 from open dataset of Environmental Management Bureau (EMB) Official Social Media Sites. This project aims to depict the AQI trend for some locations in a very understandable manner. This also tries to visualize the effect of recent issues/conditions of our country to air quality.

This data visualization project shows the Air Quality Index (AQI) for some locations in NCR, Region 3, Region 4A, Region 4B and Region 12 from open dataset of Environmental Management Bureau (EMB) Official Social Media Sites. This project aims to depict the AQI trend for some locations in a very understandable manner. This also tries to visualize the effect of recent issues/conditions of our country to air quality.

This data visualization project aims to create an awareness to the PH existing commercial power plants connected to our National Electric Grid across the country. This also calculated the estimates of Lifecycle of GHG emissions (Theoretical) (g CO2 eq/kWh) for broad categories of electricity generation technologies in reference with IPCC’s Special Report on Renewable Energy Sources and Climate Change Mitigation Report (2012).

name: Public Utility Data Liberation Project
description: The Public Utility Data Liberation (PUDL) project takes US energy system information that’s already publicly available, and makes it publicly usable, by cleaning, standardizing, and cross-linking utility data from different sources in a single database.

SDGs.evidenceText: Substantially increasing the share of renewable energy in the global energy mix and promoting investment in energy infrastructure will require transparency in resource planning decisions and in the models that underpin energy system data. Transparency in resource planning and open energy system models must be built on open and accessible energy system data.

name: PublicLab Plots2
description: A collaborative knowledge-exchange platform in Rails.

SDGs.evidenceText: Pursuing environmental justice through community science and open technology

name: PyPSA
description: Python for Power System Analysis is an open-source python environment for state-of-the-art energy system modelling.

SDGs.evidenceText: This project tends to help to eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere,

For simulating and optimising modern power systems that include features such as conventional generators with unit commitment, variable wind and solar generation, storage units, coupling to other energy sectors, and mixed alternating and direct current networks.

This project is relevant in terms of total electricity/energy system least-cost investment optimization (using linear network equations, over several snapshots simultaneously for optimization of generation and storage dispatch and investment in the capacities of generation)
This project will help in monitoring total greenhouse gas emissions per year

organizations.name: Energy System Modelling Group at the Institute for Automation and Applied Informatics

name: qAIRamap open source
description: Open source platform for mobile and fixed air quality monitoring.

SDGs.evidenceText: We aim to reduce the number of deaths and illnesses due to pollutants in the air, working together with the government and the private sector to implement action plans to improve air quality.

This is a great opportunity for qAIRa because people are going to demand to know what the air they breathe is like where they go, where they work and where they live. Companies are also changing their Corporate Social Responsibility strategies and are increasingly aware that consumers will agree to buy their products or services, only to the extent that they are respectful of the environment and society. We believe that "knowing your air" will be (in some places it already is) a human need yet to be discovered.
At qAIRa we work with drone technology to carry out forest monitoring and learn about the air quality in this area together with local communities.

name: QuanTB
description: QuanTB is an electronic quantification and early warning system designed to improve procurement processes, ordering, and supply planning for tuberculosis (TB) treatment.

SDGs.evidenceText: When used on a regular basis, QuanTB serves as an early warning system by providing information on actual versus planned consumption, impending expiries, and stock-outs of medicines.

name: Redirect 2% - redirectioneaza.ro
description: Redirect 2% - redirectioneaza.ro - is a project which helps non-governmental organizations raise funds, by making it easier for citizens to fill out a specific form which allows them to donate 2% of their income tax to an NGO. The platform allows an NGO to create an account and fill in the data relevant to their donation form. It allows citizens to pick an NGOs from the ones that have filled in their data, and then fill the redirection form out with the citizen's own data, before printing it and singing it.

name: Redirectioneaza
description: Redirectioneaza.ro contains information on over 2.700 NGOs that can be supported through a simple process of redirecting 3.5% of income tax. By digitizing the 230 form, we have eliminated the need for direct contact between NGOs and their supporters, as many organizations do not have the necessary resources to gather these forms offline.

SDGs.evidenceText: Every year, any citizen can choose to redirect 3.5% of their income tax to a cause they believe in and want to support. However, most never do so for two reasons: a cumbersome process and a lack of centralized information about the NGOs they could support. Moreover, NGOs also face the difficulty of spreading their appeals for redirection to very large audiences, in a simple way, without using up additional resources. Redirectioneaza.ro contains information on over 2.700 NGOs that can be supported through a simple process of redirecting 3.5% of income tax. By digitizing the 230 form, we have eliminated the need for direct contact between NGOs and their supporters, as many organizations do not have the necessary resources to gather these forms offline.

name: Reveal
description: Reveal is a Digital Global Good that uses spatial intelligence to drive delivery of life-saving interventions.

SDGs.evidenceText: Reveal supports microplanning and mobilization of resources, including basic social services, financial aid, or food aid.
Support the planning and delivery of food aid and nutrition resources to last mile communities.
Support the planning and delivery of health intervention campaigns including malaria, vaccination (childhood and COVAX), and neglected tropical diseases.
Provide support for water quality monitoring and water point availability.

name: Socially Sustainable Neighbourhood
description: A python project to evaluate who is most affected by neighbourhood planning decisions.

SDGs.evidenceText: To support the planning of socially sustainable neighbourhoods

organizations.name: Sustainable Building Research Group - Chalmers University of Technology

name: Soul Medicine
description: Bite-sized support for survivors of abuse, available online or sent direct to your email inbox

SDGs.evidenceText: This solution supports survivors of gender-based violence to heal and thrive.

name: StarHealth
description: An embedded website toolbar and SMS helpline that allows audiences to check whether their doctor is registered and in good standing, whether their hospital/treatment is covered by Kenya’s National Health Insurance Fund (NHIF), and where the nearest specialist health service is for their ailment. Localised versions of the HealthTools also run in South Africa (where it focuses on helping users confirm that their traditional circumcision surgeon is legit, with a hotline for bogus surgeons), and Nigeria (where it includes tools for checking whether users have been overcharged for medicine, plus whether their hospitals are legit/registered) and Tanzania (where it includes gender-based violence helplines).

SDGs.evidenceText: The tools are explicitly focused on providing the public with localised, and in some cases personalised, information on healthcare options to help ensure they take informed decision on health issues, ranging from which doctors and hospitals they use, to whether their medicine/treatment choices are cost effective. The tools also help users report suspected abuse, or danger, to health authorities.

name: Statwig
description: Solution to track vaccine supply chain in a tranparent way using blockchain to reduce wastage

name: Terrastories
description: An open-source application for mapping place-based oral histories. Terrastories is a geostorytelling application built to enable local communities to locate and map their own oral storytelling traditions about places of significant meaning or value to them. Terrastories is designed to be entirely offline-compatible

SDGs.evidenceText: Terrastories pertains to Target 4.7 insofar as the application promotes young learners, in particular from Indigenous communities, to gain appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development, in their own language and using materials that directly relate to their lands and communities.

Terrastories pertains to Target 11.4 insofar as the application serves as a resource for protecting a community's intangible cultural heritage, in the form of oral histories and traditional knowledge about the lands.

name: The Atrium
description: An inter-agency platform that allows any UN entity to learn about blockchain, share project details and engage on a community forum; The Atrium runs a private Ethereum blockchain that allows users to earn badges and launch their own blockchain applications easily.

SDGs.evidenceText: The Atrium is a blockchain-based collaboration tool where the UN community can plant and grow ideas

name: The Open Source Spatial Electrification Tool
description: OnSSET is an open source, GIS-based tool for developing electrification investment scenarios towards achieving universal access to electricity in accordance with SDG7.

SDGs.evidenceText: OnSSET focuses on SDG7, particularly target 7.1 which is to "ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern energy services". The tool identifies the least-cost technology (grid-extension, mini-grid or stand-alone technologies) to meet the electricity demand in each settlement in a country or region.

organizations.name: KTH Royal Institute of Technology - division of Energy Systems

name: The Tor Project
description: Free & open source privacy software providing secure and private web access.

SDGs.evidenceText: This project is relevant to Goal 16, Promote peaceful and inclusive societies for sustainable development, provide access to justice for all and build effective, accountable and inclusive institutions at all levels, particularly Goal 16.10:, “Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.” The Tor Project’s mission is to advance human rights and freedoms by creating and deploying free and open source anonymity and privacy technologies, supporting their unrestricted availability and use, and furthering their scientific and popular understanding.  Privacy and anonymity technologies like Tor make it possible for people in countries where governments censor the internet to bypass that censorship and freely access public information. Our work supports the human right to access information, which is fundamental to effective, accountable, and inclusive institutions. Some examples of Tor’s importance are included below: (1) In a report on the promotion and protection of the right to freedom of opinion and expression (A/HRC/29/32) to the UN Human Rights Council, Special Rapporteur David Kaye wrote that Tor, alongside encryption, maybe the only way for some individuals to exercise their “freedom to seek, receive, and impart information and ideas.” Kaye also writes: “Some states impose content-based, often discriminatory restrictions or criminalize online expression, intimidating political opposition and dissenters and applying defamation and lese-majesty laws to silence journalists, defenders and activists. A VPN connection, or use of Tor or a proxy server, combined with encryption, may be the only way in which an individual is able to access or share information in such environments.” (2) Tor is widely used in Russia to access international news as the Kremlin rapidly increases internet censorship (Washington Post link included below), (3) Tor is recommended to journalists who need to protect themselves against surveillance to do their work (Freedom of the Press Foundation)

name: Thinking Machines
description: Tool that helps link and overlay different datasets from government, NGOs and businesses for better decision making

name: Treejer Protocol
description: Connecting funders to rural planters worldwide

SDGs.evidenceText: Most of Treejer's users in the tree plantation side are among vulnerable communities in developing countries in LatAm, Africa and Middle East. By onboarding them, we provide them with a new channel of income. Some of them were unemployed before working with us. Also, our Rural Development Fund, supports local communities in areas other than environmental work. We aim to distribute micr0-loans and micro-grants from this fund to eligible planters working with Treejer. Microfinance and land ownership are key ways to eliminate poverty.
We support regenerative agriculture and some of our projects are part of agroforestry and provide sustainable food supply to families involved.

We're building technologies that promote the empowerment of women. This is mainly done by providing fair and equal access to remote job opportunities in places where women have less opportunities. We encourage rural ambassadors to invite more women as planters in their local communities.

By reducing stormwater runoff and soil erosion, trees and plants can aid communities with water quality issues. Trees help collect nutrients that might otherwise be washed away from the soil. Some of our communities plant the trees in strategic places for better management of rain water. Forests slow the flow of water by intercepting precipitation and by consuming water in the ground.

One of the most important features of Treejer protocol is providing bankless payments to unbanked individuals as they contribute to the environmental causes. We have a special focus on onboarding communities from global south and provide them with decent job opportunities as planters. All women and men receive equal pay for work of equal value. In addition, we work with contributors from various countries. Currently, most of our core contributors are immigrants.

By developing open-source technologies on public blockchains, we're building sustainable, resilient and transparent infrastructures specially for communities in least developed countries. Treejer's innovations has already added financial, technological and technical support to African, LatAm and Middle Eastern people.

Using some of the key features of web 3.0, Treejer empowers the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status. When working with local communities in the supply side, we do our best to minimize the cost for them. For instance, Treejer sponsors blockchain transaction fees for rural planters and charges planters $0 costs to use Treejer. We consider costless and incentivized inclusion as a key design principle in product development.

Treejer helps locals to protect and safeguard their natural heritage by providing financial support. There are communities who plant trees in public rural areas. Their forestation efforts provides safe and inclusive access to green and public spaces. Also, forests facilitate mitigation and adaptation to climate change, and resilience to disasters specially by flood prevention.

Climate change poses a clear and present danger to our entire civilization. The consequences are already evident and will be disastrous unless we act quickly. We need to make the necessary changes to protect the earth via education, open innovation, and adherence to our climate obligations. Governments lack enough coordination tools, but web3 is providing unprecedented opportunities with new incentive structures globally. As a web3-native and open-source project, we're experimenting for a faster and multi-stakeholder climate innovation.

This is the most relevant SDG to the works of Treejer. We continue to make our contribution to building a sustainable green future for everyone in the world with the help of new technologies. We connect funders to rural planters worldwide to protect forests even in remote and unbanked communities. Forests have direct impact on biodiversity and Treejer facilitates forest financing.

name: U-Report
description: Free social messaging tool and a real-time information system that allows community participation.

name: UNICEF eTools
description: eTools is an online platform that strengthens UNICEF country programme management for results.

name: UNICEF MagicBox
description: With MagicBox, Unicef can gain critical insights into the needs of vulnerable populations, and make more informed decisions to respond to disaster, epidemics and other challenges.

name: ur-scape
description: ur-scape is an open-source spatial planning tool designed to support sustainable futures in rapidly developing urban and rural regions where data is often difficult to access and uneven in quality, and where development needs are especially urgent and challenging. ur-scape does this by bringing diverse kinds of data together and encouraging people to explore the data intuitively and in real-time.  ur-scape helps city makers, be they governments, businesses or communities, improve the quality of planning and design decisions. It helps develop liveable neighbourhoods, build responsive towns, reduce city ‘stress points’ (flooding, traffic snarls, poverty) and enhance ‘sweet spots’ (accessible, equitable, economically vibrant), and progress towards strategic development goals (regional, national and SDGs).  Developed by the Urban-Rural Systems (URS) team at Future Cities Laboratory (FCL), ur-scape is supported by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the Swiss Secretariat for Economic Affairs (SECO). Pilot implementation of the ur-scape tool is supported by the municipal planning authorities of the city of Bandung, the Indonesian Ministry of Agrarian Affairs and Spatial Planning (MASP), and the Bauhaus Weimar University.

organizations.name: Swiss State Secretary for Economic Affairs (SECO)

name: Uwazi
description: Uwazi is a web-based database application designed for human rights defenders to manage collections of information, including documents, evidence, cases and complaints.

SDGs.evidenceText: We collaborate with local activist groups, national human rights institutions, large international NGOs and many organisations in between. Some of our partners specialise in specific issues such as arbitrary arrest, freedom of expression, historical memory, and transitional justice, while others focus on human rights-related mechanisms such as the United Nations Human Rights Treaty System. Beyond their shared commitment to dignity and freedom, our partners have an important thing in common: they achieve greater impact when the information they need is easy to access, navigate and understand.

name: VictimsOfIntolerance
description: Hate crimes monitor for political motivated assaults in Brazil.

SDGs.evidenceText: This project is an effort to reunite reported cases of victims of political violence, motivated by political intolerance. There is a crescent number of attacks being reported in the electoral context,  so mapping this cases is a form to show the advance of intolerance in the country.

This project is an effort to reunite reported cases of victims of political violence, motivated by political intolerance. There is a crescent number of attacks being reported in the electoral context,  so mapping this cases is a form to show the advance of intolerance in the country.

name: VR for Schools
description: Educational virtual reality content for the Nigerian junior secondary school curriculum.

name: Wonder Tree
description: Augmented Reality Games for Children with Social Needs

name: Your Priorities
description: Your Priorities is a cloud-based online idea generation, deliberation & decision-making platform connecting governments and citizens, evolving since 2008 in thousands of projects, connecting millions of citizens to governments.

SDGs.evidenceText: Your Priorities is used in cities around the world enabling citizens to participate in order to help cities take better decisions on budgets and policies. An example is Better Reykjavik, a platform run in collaboration with the city of Reykjavik since the year 2010..

Your Priorities helps governments around the world include citizens in decision making. Your Priorities has been used in over 25 countries on 5 continents. Here is an example on how the Scottish Parliament used Your Priorities ensure citizens can participate in decision making.

repositories.name: Your Priorities API & Progressive Web App
Your Priorities Active Citizen AI Library
